item.title: Kokilaben Hospital opens India’s first certified endometriosis clinic - Healthcare Radius
item.description:
Kokilaben Hospital opens India’s first certified endometriosis clinic

Publication Date: January 17, 2025 Source: Healthcare Radius

Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital has achieved a significant milestone by opening India’s first certified Endometriosis Clinic, recognized by the European Endometriosis League (EEL). This clinic aims to provide comprehensive, evidence-based care for women suffering from endometriosis, a condition affecting millions yet often underdiagnosed.

  • The clinic is designated as the first and only certified endometriosis clinic in India.
  • It aims to provide a multidisciplinary approach to care that addresses the chronic nature of endometriosis.
  • The certification reflects adherence to strict international treatment guidelines.
  • Emphasizes the importance of education, awareness, and early diagnosis in women's health.
  • Focuses on the link between endometriosis and infertility.
“This certification is a significant milestone in our mission to transform endometriosis care in India.” - Dr. Anshumala Shukla-Kulkarni

This groundbreaking clinic underscores Kokilaben Hospital's commitment to enhancing women's healthcare in India, providing hope and improving the quality of life for patients suffering from endometriosis.

item.title: 5 Floor Exercises to Lose Belly Fat - News18
item.description:
5 Floor Exercises to Lose Belly Fat

Publication Date: January 19, 2025 | Source: News 18

This article outlines some effective floor exercises that can help in reducing belly fat.

  • Crunches: A classic exercise targeting the rectus abdominis muscles.
  • Bicycle Crunches: Engages both the upper and lower abdominal muscles.
  • Russian Twists: Excellent for targeting the oblique muscles.
  • Plank: A full-body exercise engaging core muscles.
  • Leg Raises: Targets the lower abdominal muscles.
These exercises are essential for anyone looking to strengthen their core and achieve a flatter stomach.

Incorporating these exercises into your routine can lead to significant improvements in core strength and the reduction of belly fat.

item.title: The one heart test all marathoners must know: CT Calcium score - The Times of India
item.description:
The One Heart Test All Marathoners Must Know: CT Calcium Score

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article discusses the importance of the CT Calcium score test for marathoners, emphasizing its role in assessing heart health and risk of heart disease.

  • The CT Calcium score provides an indication of heart disease risk.
  • Marathoners are advised to consider this test as part of their health routine.
  • Understanding the scores can help in taking preventive measures.
  • The test is non-invasive and can be helpful for athletes of all levels.
"Knowing your calcium score can be a game changer for your heart health."

In conclusion, the CT Calcium score is a crucial assessment tool for marathoners wanting to monitor and maintain their heart health effectively.

item.title: 18 percent women have cervical cancer in India, say doctors - The Siasat Daily
item.description:
Cervical Cancer Affects 18% of Women in India, Say Experts

Date: Not specified Source: Siasat.com

As cervical cancer month is observed in January, doctors emphasize the importance of awareness regarding the disease, its symptoms, and preventative measures.

  • Cervical cancer is primarily caused by the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is rising in prevalence in India.
  • Dr Nasreen Ashfaq reports that about 18% of women in India currently suffer from cervical cancer.
  • The disease is the second leading cause of death among women after breast cancer.
  • The government has initiated screening tests including pap smears for early detection and treatment.
  • HPV is a sexually transmitted virus that can lead to cervical cancer over a long period.
  • Vaccination against HPV is critical for prevention, preferably administered to girls aged 11-13.
“Prevention is better than curing cervical cancer because it is the only cancer that can be completely prevented by vaccination.” - Dr Amreen

In conclusion, increasing awareness and preventive health measures, including vaccination and regular screenings, are vital for lowering the incidence of cervical cancer among women in India.

item.title: The hidden danger of late-night social media - The Hans India
item.description:
The Hidden Danger of Late-Night Social Media

Publication Date: 2023

Source: BMC Public Health

This study highlights a concerning relationship between late-night screen time, particularly from short videos, and hypertension among young and middle-aged individuals.

  • A study by The First Hospital of Hebei Medical University found a link between long screen time at night and high blood pressure.
  • The research analyzed data from 4,318 participants regarding their screen habits and health.
  • Prolonged screen time disrupts sleep patterns and increases stress, leading to higher blood pressure.
  • The study suggests limiting screen exposure in the evening to maintain healthy sleep and blood pressure levels.
  • High blood pressure impacts over 1.3 billion adults globally and is a major health concern.
“Watching short videos before bedtime was significantly associated with essential hypertension,” the researchers stated.

In conclusion, the study urges individuals to manage their screen time, especially at night, to protect their health and well-being.

item.title: Should you start lifting weights? - Hindustan Times
item.description:
You’ll stay healthier for longer if you’re strong

Date: Jan 19, 2025 Source: The Economist

The article discusses the growing trend of strength training and its health benefits, emphasizing the importance of muscle strength for overall well-being as people age.

  • Strength training is gaining popularity, with gyms shifting focus from cardio machines to weightlifting equipment.
  • The World Health Organisation recommends muscle-strengthening exercises at least twice a week.
  • A 2020 study showed that only 10% to 30% of adults meet strength training guidelines.
  • Strength training can reduce the risk of heart diseases, diabetes, and cancer.
  • Sarcopenia, the loss of muscle with age, is a significant health issue that can lead to frailty and increased risk of falls.
  • Even older adults can benefit from regular strength training to maintain functionality and health.
"Even for people in their 80s, a bit of pumping iron can work wonders."

In conclusion, incorporating strength training into regular exercise routines can lead to a healthier and longer life, especially as we age.

item.title: 10 fruits you should include in breakfast for a healthier diet - Hindustan Times
item.description:
10 Fruits to Include in Your Breakfast for a Healthier Diet

Publication Date: January 18, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

This article highlights ten fruits that you should incorporate into your breakfast to enhance your diet with important nutrients and flavors.

  • Bananas: Lower blood pressure and aid digestion.
  • Blueberries: Loaded with antioxidants for brain health.
  • Cantaloupe: Hydrates and provides vitamins A and C.
  • Cranberries: Support digestion and heart health.
  • Grapefruit: Rich in vitamins C and A, potassium, and fiber.
  • Kiwi: Aids digestion and supports heart health.
  • Raspberries: May have cancer-fighting properties.
  • Orange Juice: Enhances iron absorption in the body.
  • Strawberries: High in antioxidants supporting heart health.
  • Watermelon: Hydrates and protects heart health.
“Fruits are rich in potassium, fiber, vitamin C, and folate—nutrients essential for your body.”

Incorporating these fruits into your daily breakfast can improve your overall health and provide a delicious start to your day.

item.title: 7 small changes in our habits that protect our heart diseases - The Times of India
item.description:
7 Small Changes in Our Habits to Protect Against Heart Diseases

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not provided

This article discusses seven actionable lifestyle changes that can help reduce the risk of heart diseases, emphasizing the importance of habit modification for heart health.

  • Increase physical activity regularly.
  • Eat a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables.
  • Reduce salt and sugar intake.
  • Maintain healthy body weight.
  • Quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption.
  • Manage stress through mindfulness or other techniques.
  • Get regular health check-ups for early detection.
“Small, consistent changes can lead to significant improvements in heart health.”

Adapting these habits not only protects your heart but enhances overall well-being.

item.title: Private vacant site turns dumping ground in Noombal - DTNEXT
item.description:
Residents Demand Action as Vacant Lot in Noombal Becomes Dumping Ground

Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Residents and commuters of Noombal are calling for immediate action from local authorities regarding a vacant site that has become a severe health hazard due to accumulated garbage and stagnant sewage.

  • Garbage has not been cleared for over six months.
  • Health risks are particularly severe for children and senior citizens.
  • Complaints to authorities have not resulted in consistent clean-up efforts.
  • The area has become a breeding ground for mosquitoes, threatening residents' health.
  • Residents suggest penalties for improper waste disposal and maintenance of the site.
“The so-called clean-up work was for namesake only.” – Senthil Kumar, civic activist

Residents are frustrated by the lack of civic sense and inadequate municipal response, emphasizing the necessity for ongoing maintenance and preventive measures.

item.title: Weight loss pills Ozempic, Wegovy and Trizepatide enter Indian market - The Financial Express
item.description:
Weight Loss Pills Ozempic, Wegovy, and Trizepatide Enter Indian Market

Date: October 2023

Source: Financial Express

Revolutionary anti-obesity drugs, including Wegovy, Ozempic, and Eli Lilly’s tirzepatide, are set to enter the Indian market this year, promising to shake up the pharmaceutical landscape.

  • Eli Lilly anticipates a positive response as it prepares to launch its drug tirzepatide, or Mounjaro.
  • Competitor Novo Nordisk may expedite the launch of Wegovy to match Eli Lilly's timeline.
  • These drugs have significantly impacted markets in the West, with Novo Nordisk's share price soaring and high prescription rates in the US.
  • In the second quarter of 2023, Eli Lilly’s Zepbound made $1.24 billion and Mounjaro made $3.09 billion.
  • High-profile endorsements from celebrities may influence the drugs’ popularity in India.
  • Obesity is a growing concern in India, with the adult obesity rate tripling, emphasizing the need for accessible treatment options.
  • Domestic companies are racing to develop affordable alternatives to these new drugs.
“Obesity is a serious concern among India’s adult population...” – Eli Lilly spokesperson

The introduction of these medications presents opportunities for improved treatment of obesity in India, addressing a critical health issue and potentially transforming the pharmaceutical sector.

item.title: Weight loss pills Ozempic, Wegovy and Trizepatide enter indian market - The Financial Express
item.description:
Weight Loss Pills Ozempic, Wegovy, and Trizepatide Enter Indian Market

Publication Date: October 2023, Source: Financial Express

In a significant development, revolutionary anti-obesity drugs Wegovy, Ozempic, and tirzepatide are set to enter the Indian market this year, promising to address the growing obesity crisis in the country.

  • These drugs have already seen success in Western markets, leading to a rise in shareholder value for manufacturers like Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly.
  • Over 65% of drug prescriptions in the US in 2022 were for Ozempic alone.
  • Prominent celebrities like Elon Musk and Oprah Winfrey have endorsed these medications.
  • Obesity rates have tripled among adults in India, highlighting the urgent need for effective treatments.
  • Domestic companies are also racing to produce budget-friendly alternatives to these drugs.
“As per the India Economic Survey 2024, obesity is a serious concern among India’s adult population with the adult obesity rate having more than tripled.” - Eli Lilly spokesman

The anticipated arrival of these weight loss medications could transform the Indian pharma landscape, presenting both challenges and opportunities for local companies.

item.title: 6 Foods To Add To Diet For Weight Loss Affected By Inflammation And Stress - Mint
item.description:
6 Foods To Add To Diet For Weight Loss Affected By Inflammation And Stress

Publication Date: Unknown, Source: Mint

Struggling with weight gain? Chronic inflammation and stress hinder progress, but certain foods can combat these issues and promote healthy weight loss.

  • Avocados: Rich in monounsaturated fats, potassium, and magnesium, avocados reduce inflammation and improve satiety.
  • Fatty Fish: Omega-3-rich fish reduce inflammation, enhance brain health, lower stress, improve mood, and curb cravings.
  • Blueberries: Antioxidant-rich tiny berries that reduce inflammation, stabilize blood sugar, and lower stress hormones.
  • Spinach: Leafy greens rich in magnesium and phytonutrients that relax muscles, reduce stress, and are low-calorie and fiber-rich.
  • Turmeric: Contains curcumin, a powerful anti-inflammatory; add it to soups, smoothies, or teas, and pair with black pepper.
  • Green Tea: Rich in catechins and theanine, green tea reduces stress, enhances fat-burning, and lowers inflammation.

By including these foods in your diet, you can help mitigate the effects of inflammation and stress while promoting weight loss.

item.title: In the quest for an anti-ageing drug - Deccan Herald
item.description:
In the quest for an anti-ageing drug

Date: 18 January 2025
Source: Unspecified

As global lifespans steadily increase, the search for effective anti-ageing drugs accelerates, potentially transforming health management in older age.

  • Current trends indicate that by 2030, one in six people worldwide will be aged sixty or older.
  • Ageing leads to a decline in health and increases the risk of chronic diseases.
  • Dr. Brian Kennedy's research focuses on targeting nutrient-sensing pathways to extend lifespan and healthspan.
  • Metformin, primarily known for treating Type 2 diabetes, may offer potential anti-ageing benefits.
  • The World Health Organisation recognizes ageing as a disease, enabling the exploration of existing drugs for age-related health improvements.
  • The TAME trial aims to assess Metformin's effectiveness in addressing age-related conditions.
  • Concerns about the efficacy and environmental impact of widespread Metformin use are raised.
“Experts do not recommend using either Rapamycin or Metformin as anti-ageing drugs until clinical trials confirm their benefits.”

In conclusion, while promising, the field of anti-ageing drugs requires further research and clinical validation to fully understand their efficacy and implications.

item.title: Mpox cases in Africa surpass 77,800 as death toll climbs to 1,321: Africa CDC - Macau Business
item.description:
Mpox Cases in Africa Surpass 77,800 with 1,321 Deaths, Reports Africa CDC

Publication Date: Recent report from Africa CDC

The recent report by the Africa CDC indicates a significant increase in mpox cases across Africa, with 77,888 cases reported since the start of 2024. The rising death toll now stands at 1,321, with Sierra Leone confirming its first outbreak on January 10.

  • 77,888 mpox cases reported since the beginning of 2024.
  • Sierra Leone confirmed its first cases, bringing total affected countries to 21.
  • 13 countries currently experiencing active virus transmission.
  • 4 countries have gone over 90 days without confirmed cases.
  • Central Africa remains the most affected region.
  • Intensified response and decentralization of testing emphasized by the Africa CDC.
“Countries need to decentralize mpox testing, enhance laboratory infrastructure, and combat misinformation about the virus.” - Jean Kaseya, Africa CDC Director-General

Mpox, previously known as monkeypox, was first detected in laboratory monkeys in 1958 and is transmitted through body fluids and respiratory droplets.

item.title: Rising mumps cases prompt health advisory for parents and schools - The Times of India
item.description:
Rising mumps cases prompt health advisory for parents and schools

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: [Source not provided]

Health authorities have issued a warning to parents and schools due to a surge in mumps cases. The advisory highlights the importance of vaccination and monitoring symptoms.

  • Mumps cases are on the rise in several communities.
  • Health officials emphasize the importance of vaccinations in preventing outbreaks.
  • Parents are urged to check their children's vaccination status.
"Vaccination is key to keeping our children safe from mumps and other preventable diseases."

Parents and schools are advised to remain vigilant and adhere to public health guidelines to control the spread of mumps.

item.title: Heart attacks and winter - The Financial Express
item.description:
The Impact of Cold Weather on Heart Health

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Financial Express

Cold temperatures can have several adverse effects on the body, increasing the risk of heart-related issues due to vasoconstriction and heightened blood pressure.

  • Low temperatures lead to vasoconstriction, reducing blood flow and increasing frostbite risk.
  • Cold weather increases strain on the heart, elevating blood pressure and the risk of heart attacks and strokes.
  • Thicker blood due to cold enhances the likelihood of clot formation.
  • Physical exertion in cold, such as shoveling snow, adds stress on the heart.
  • Patients with pre-existing conditions must monitor their health and avoid exposure to cold.
“It is critical for individuals to take precautions like dressing warmly, avoiding overexertion, and monitoring blood pressure during winter.”

Prolonged exposure to cold can also impact other organs, highlighting the necessity for care during the winter months.

item.title: Shocking truth about elderberry supplements that experts want you to know - India Today
item.description:
Shocking truth about elderberry supplements that experts want you to know

Published On: Jan 19, 2025 | Source: indiatodayglobal

Every year, Americans catch an estimated 1 billion cases of the common cold, with many seeking remedies such as elderberry supplements. Consumers spent $175 million on these supplements last year, but experts are divided on their effectiveness.

  • Small studies suggest elderberry may reduce the duration and severity of colds and flu.
  • One study indicated elderberry might shorten flu symptoms by four days compared to a placebo.
  • Not all research agrees; some studies found no benefits for flu patients in emergency rooms.
  • Elderberry supplements are not FDA verified and caution is advised due to potential risks from raw elderberries.
  • While they may offer minor relief, more substantial research is needed to confirm effectiveness.
“Do not spend money on elderberry supplements until more information is available.” - Michael Macknin, Professor Emeritus

In summary, while elderberry supplements are popular and have some reported benefits, the scientific community urges caution and calls for more extensive research to validate their efficacy.

item.title: Mosquito-borne diseases reported even in winter - The Times of India
item.description:
Mosquito-borne Diseases Reported Even in Winter

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

Recent reports indicate a concerning trend of mosquito-borne diseases being detected during the winter season, traditionally considered off-peak for such illnesses.

  • Winter months are usually associated with a decline in mosquito activity.
  • Health officials warn that changing weather patterns are allowing mosquitoes to thrive longer.
  • Despite the cold, cases of diseases like dengue and chikungunya are emerging.
  • Public health measures are urged to adapt to these new realities.
“We need to rethink our strategies for controlling mosquito populations year-round,” said a leading health expert.

The uptick in mosquito-borne diseases during winter highlights the need for ongoing public health vigilance and adaptation of prevention strategies.

item.title: Scientists find sepsis molecule, to boost treatments for critically ill patients - Nagaland Post
item.description:
Scientists find sepsis molecule, to boost treatments for critically ill patients

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Nagaland Post

A team of US scientists from Oregon Health & Science University (OHSU) has discovered how a molecule found in certain bacteria contributes to blood clotting during sepsis, a severe condition responsible for approximately eight million deaths annually. This breakthrough could enhance treatment options for critically ill patients.

  • The molecule, lipopolysaccharide (LPS), activates blood proteins that trigger clotting.
  • A specific type of LPS, O26:B6, is identified as particularly effective in causing clotting issues.
  • The research was conducted using nonhuman primates and published in the Journal of Biological Chemistry.
  • Factor XII, a coagulating protein activated by LPS, is highlighted as a potential target for therapies aiming to prevent dangerous clots without causing bleeding.
  • The implications of this research point towards the development of precision therapies for different bacterial strains causing sepsis.
“People who are born without factor XII are healthy and don’t bleed abnormally. That makes it a great target for therapies — blocking it might help stop dangerous clots without causing bleeding.” - Joseph Shatzel

This groundbreaking research presents a promising avenue for innovative treatments targeting sepsis, potentially saving countless lives in the future.

item.title: H5N1 In US: Department Of Health Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Scare - TheHealthSite
item.description:
H5N1 In US: Department Of Health Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Scare

Date: Not specified Source: The Health Site

The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has announced a significant investment to accelerate the development of a new bird flu vaccine in response to rising concerns about avian influenza affecting humans.

  • The federal government is addressing the surge in avian influenza cases.
  • A $590 million investment in Moderna has been revealed.
  • This funding builds on a previous $176 million grant from July.
  • The vaccine aims to target H5N1 and other strains affecting various animals.
  • mRNA technology is highlighted for its rapid development capabilities.
“Because it can be manufactured quickly, if we began to see something sweep across the country quickly, it would allow us to move fast, to give the first line of protection to the American people.” - Dawn O'Connell, HHS

In the wake of recent bird flu cases, including one death in the U.S., the urgency to create effective vaccines is rising, particularly with the emergence of the H5N1 strain.

item.title: Kids exposed to Zika in the womb show development delays - The Hindu
item.description:
Kids exposed to Zika in the womb show development delays

Published on: January 18, 2025

Source: The Hindu

This article discusses a study revealing that children exposed to the Zika virus in utero face greater risks of neurodevelopmental delays, even if they were born without congenital Zika syndrome.

  • A study published in the journal Pediatrics assessed 148 mother-infant pairs, comparing Zika-exposed children to a control group.
  • Children exposed to the virus showed almost three times the risk of adverse developmental outcomes.
  • Language function was notably affected, with 35% exhibiting language delays.
  • The timing of maternal infection is critical; first-trimester infections lead to higher risks of delays.
  • Identifying asymptomatic infections during pregnancy is challenging, complicating potential cases.
“This suggests a high potential for adverse paediatric outcomes in children born to mothers with confirmed Zika virus infection.”

The findings emphasize the need for awareness regarding Zika and its potential long-term effects on affected children.

item.title: US Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Fears - TheHealthSite
item.description:
H5N1 In US: Department Of Health Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Scare

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: The Health Site

The federal government of the United States is intensifying efforts to address the rising threat of bird flu in humans. With a spike in avian influenza cases this year, officials are focusing on creating new vaccines, including mRNA-based ones, to prevent a potential pandemic.

  • The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) announced a $590 million investment in Moderna to accelerate vaccine development.
  • This funding complements a previous $176 million grant given to the company in July.
  • The new vaccine targets bird flu strains currently affecting wild birds, poultry, and dairy cows.
  • Dawn O'Connell from HHS emphasizes the rapid development capability of mRNA technology.
  • Bird flu cases have been rising in the U.S., with one reported death from the H5N1 strain.
“Because it can be manufactured quickly, if we began to see something sweep across the country quickly, it would allow us to move fast, to give the first line of protection to the American people.” - Dawn O'Connell

With the increase in bird flu cases, the U.S. government is taking urgent actions to prevent potential pandemic situations through rapid vaccine development and health measures.

item.title: US Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Scare - TheHealthSite
item.description:
US Speeds Up Development Of New Bird Flu Vaccine Amid Pandemic Scare

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] Source: The Health Site

The federal government is intensifying efforts to address the rising threat of bird flu in humans with a major investment in vaccine development to prevent a potential pandemic.

  • The HHS has invested $590 million in Moderna for bird flu vaccine development.
  • This funding is in addition to a previous $176 million grant awarded in July.
  • The vaccine targets strains currently affecting wild birds, poultry, and dairy cows.
  • Using mRNA technology allows for rapid development and flexibility in response to emerging threats.
"Because it can be manufactured quickly, if we began to see something sweep across the country quickly, it would allow us to move fast, to give the first line of protection to the American people." - Dawn O'Connell, HHS

This initiative reflects the urgency of addressing public health concerns regarding avian influenza as cases rise.

item.title: Just 1 Drink a Day Could Raise Your Risk of Liver Damage, Cancer - Healthline
item.description:
How Much Alcohol Is Safe to Drink Without Putting Your Health at Risk?

Publication Date: January 14, 2025

Source: Healthline

A new federal report indicates that even moderate alcohol consumption can increase the risk of liver damage and certain cancers, raising questions about safe drinking levels.

  • A new federal report shows that one drink per day could raise the risk of liver damage and several cancers.
  • The report follows a recommendation by the U.S. Surgeon General on safe alcohol consumption that highlighted the health risks of moderate drinking.
  • Experts generally agree that the less a person drinks, the lower their disease risk and other health issues.
  • Safe alcohol consumption may vary from person to person depending on their age, genetic make-up, health history, and general lifestyle habits.
“Even one drink per day can pose health risks, including an increased risk of certain cancers such as breast, esophageal, and colorectal cancer.” - Wael Harb, MD

In conclusion, it is generally safer to minimize alcohol consumption, with some experts advising that avoiding alcohol altogether may be the best choice for health.
